w:r.w:t: SMAP is developed in MATLAB using object-oriented programming. Its functionality is broken down into many modules. Modules are implemented by extending basic classes and provide specific functionality, but also information about the required input parameters to allow a specific GUI to be displayed for each plugin.
. Here, the SMAP object (in this case just called g) is constructed as an object of the class
the main GUI is made and many plugin objects are instantiated and their GUIs displayed within the main GUI.
and classes defining specific plugins, SMAP contains many helper functions

Most analyses in SMAP are coordinate based, i.e. they act on the fitted localizations. Thus, the main data are single-molecule coordinates and other attributes. Combined with additional information, these make a
that is shared between all plugins and can be accessed with
. Each field of this structure corresponds to one
represented as a vector. All these vectors have the same length (=number of localizations).
In case several files are loaded, localizations are just appended to the vectors, the field
denotes which file the localizations belong to.
, but containing merged (grouped) localizations. These are stored separately to be immediately available, as the task of grouping can take several seconds.
This property contains all information corresponding to individual reconstructed layers. Specifically, these are the
for the localization fields (logical vectors with
meaning the corresponding localization is used), and reconstructed images for each layer.
, here every component corresponds to one loaded file and stores all file-related information. Important fields
: Metadata associated with the raw image data file
: here all added tiff files are stored
: a subset of the raw camera frames are stored
: a structure with the fitting parameters
: A cell array with each component containing the parameters of a specific plugin that was applied to the localization data.
is a high-level method of the localization data class to access localization attributes for a defined sub-set of localizations.
is a structure with fields corresponding to attributes of the localizations.
a cell array of the fields that you want to read out. Additional parameter/value pairs describe precisely what subset of localizations you want to access.
for a full description of parameter/value pairs.

You can use this function to access filtered or unfiltered localizations, those only in a defined ROI or those displayed in the main reconstruction window. You can access localizations in specific layers, and define if to read out grouped or ungrouped localizations. This method makes it easy to define in the main GUI what part of the localizations to use for a specific analysis plugin.
needs to be a vector with a length corresponding to the number of localizations. With
you can update the grouped localizations.
All SMAP objects contain the same

object as a property. However, this object is used to share only data-specific parameters. In addition, all components can communicate via a parameter object. This is another shared object, stored as an object property
Parameters are accessed via a user-defined
MATLAB data format or object, but large structures or objects lead to loss in performance.
The main functions are defined in the
by all SMAP plugins) and accessible as:

Parameters can be synchronized with GUI controls. Whenever a user changes a control, this changes the parameter value and changes the control of any other synchronized GUI component in other plugins to the same value. This provides a simple way of synchronizing
GUI parameters between different plugins. In addition, a function can be defined that is called after a parameter is changed with
allowing any plugin to react to changes in parameters (this is similar to the
Alternatively, and probably simpler, add it in the definition of the plugin GUI with:
on how to create those) are linked to parameters. Handles to GUI controls are stored in
these are converted into a structure.
is also directly passed on to the
Editable controls that contain values (or vectors) are automatically converted to numerical variables, checkboxes are converted to
and popup menus return a structure with
Get a single GUI parameter with
. p is a structure similar to that obtain with
. Every field of p should have the same name as a GUI control element. Its value is converted back to a value/state of the specific control.
. For implementing own plugins, we recommend starting with an existing plugin or preferably with the template
. New plugins that are saved in a sub-directory of
are automatically recognized upon starting SMAP and added to the menu.
In the class constructor you can set several switches for the plugin behavior (see template for details). The GUI is automatically generated based on information in
for details). All handles to GUI components are stored in

button to start the analysis. This calls the method

To avoid opening many figure windows as outputs of plugins, there is a default output window. This is output window is created invisible if
is checked in the GUI. Every output creates a new tab. Create a new tab with
and access it via the axis handle
SMAP plugins have a simple syntax to define a GUI. However, you can also manually create a GUI by either overwriting the
. Donâ€™t forget to store handles to new GUI controls as fields in
To make use of the automatic GUI creation, change the
). In short, every control corresponds to a field in
, the name of the field is the common identifier (this will also be the name of the associated parameter). The value of the field is again a structure with the following fields:
defining the GUI control. These correspond to name, value pairs of the MATLAB
function. In case you want to pass on a cell (e.g. String of a
) you need to use double brackets
Position of the GUI control on a 7 x 4 grid in the GUI panel.
: Width of the GUI control in units of the grid (optional, default =1).
: Height of the GUI control in units of the grid (optional, default =1).
: Tool tip associated with control, this is shown when the mouse hovers over the control (optional).
, this control is hidden from view if the simple GUI is selected (optional, default=

Workflows are a collection of plugins that are chained and act sequentially on data.
For every plugin the next plugin is defined and processed data is passed on. Data is passed on as part of a
As plugins can have more than one input channel, data synchronization becomes important. By default, synchronization for multi-input plugins is via the â€˜frameâ€™ property of the
object. Then only if all input channels have a
object with the same â€˜frameâ€™ property, the workflow is called and the data object is removed from the buffers. Instead of â€˜frameâ€™ also other properties can be used for synchronization.
The buffers that pass on data between plugins are meant to carry all large data. Other parameters, especially those that do not change dynamically, are usually shared via the
The workflow itself is assembled using its GUI. Make a new workflow using SMAP
Add workflow plugins to the workflow by right-clicking on the plugin list. For each plugin you need to select which other plugin passes on the data to this plugin.
will display a graphical representation of the workflow.
To use a workflow as a fitting workflow in SMAP, you can load the workflow in the

tab by right-clicking on the tabs and selecting add workflow in the context menu. It is however more convenient to load the workflow with the Change button. But for this, the GUI controls of each workflow plugin need to be mapped to different tabs. This is done by a .txt file with the same name as the
). It needs to contain the following lines (remove %comments):
%in which tab to position the GUI
% where to position it vertically (Nx4 grid)
To generate your own workflow plugins we recommend starting with an existing plugin or the template
Workflow plugins are similar to Analysis plugins (section
), with the GUI defined in the same way. You need to implement the following methods:
If you have more than one input channel then set the number of input channels with
method is called once before starting the workflow. You can initialize the workflow here.

The ROI manager stores the positions and annotations of specific ROIs (also called sites) in many files. It is an object
and thus shared with all plugins.
Its properties contain three vectors of
that are lists with files, cells and sites (ROIs). The main properties of
: absolute position of the ROI center in nanometers
: structure which cell and file the ROI belongs to
: structure with annotations defined in the ROI GUI
: structure with results from evaluation plugins
Evaluation plugins are plugins that evaluate single ROIs, specifically single objects of the class
Usually, they are run on all ROIs of a data set and output results of the analysis.
and can be programmed in the same way as normal analysis plugins (section
The functionality is encoded in the method
Instead of obtaining localization data with
, here we recommend using analogous code
. If no Position parameters are passed on, the position of the ROI is used.
The output of the evaluation is a structure
the evaluation plugins are stored at
